DB5.description:
Description: The 1964 Aston Martin DB5 is an iconic British grand tourer, renowned for its elegant design and powerful performance. The DB5 gained legendary status as James Bond's car in the 1964 film Goldfinger, further cementing its place in automotive history.
Engine: 4.0L inline-six
Transmission: Five-speed/Manual

Horsepower: 282
Torque(lb/ft): 288
Top Speed(mph): 145
Dimensions: 98 x 179.9 x 66.1
Curb Weight(lb): 3,311
Fuel Economy(MPG): 12

DB9.description:

Transmission: Six-Speed Automatic

3000 MKII.description:

Continental GT.description:
Description: The 2003 Bentley Continental GT is a luxurious grand tourer that marked a significant shift for Bentley. It was the first model introduced after Bentley's acquisition by Volkswagen, featuring a blend of traditional craftsmanship and modern technology. This model was praised for its powerful performance, elegant design, and high-quality interior.
Engine: Twin Turbocharged 6L W12
Transmission: Six-Speed Automatic
0-60(mph): 4.7
Horsepower: 550
Torque(lb/ft): 479
Top Speed(mph): 198
Dimensions(in): 189 x 76 x 55
Curb Weight(lb): 5,071
Fuel Economy(MPG): 16

E-Type.description:
Description: The 1961 Jaguar E-Type, also known as the Jaguar XK-E in North America, is a legendary British sports car that was produced from 1961 to 1974. It was renowned for its stunning design, advanced technology, and impressive performance. The E-Type quickly became an icon in the automotive world and remains highly sought after by collectors today.
Engine: 3.8L inline-six
Transmission: Four-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 6.3
Horsepower: 265
Torque(lb/ft): 260
Top Speed(mph): 145
Dimensions(in): 175.5 x 62.25 x 96.0
Curb Weight(lb): 2,899
Fuel Economy(MPG): 22

XJ220.description:
Description:The 1992 Jaguar XJ220 is a legendary supercar produced by Jaguar in collaboration with Tom Walkinshaw Racing.The XJ220 was initially conceived as a V12-engined, four-wheel-drive concept but was later produced with a V6 engine and rear-wheel drive due to engineering and emissions requirements1. It remains an iconic piece of automotive history.
Engine: 3.5L Twin-Turbocharged V6
Transmission: Five-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 3.6
Horsepower: 542
Torque(lb/ft): 475
Top Speed(mph): 212
Dimensions(in): 194.1 x 79.1 x 45.3
Curb Weight(lb): 3,240
Fuel Economy(MPG): 27

XK120.description:
Description: The 1952 Jaguar XK120 is a classic sports car that holds a special place in automotive history. It was celebrated for its combination of performance, style, and engineering excellence.
Engine: 3.4L Inline 6
Transmission: Four-Speed manual
0-60(mph): 9.9
Horsepower: 180
Torque(lb/ft): 195
Top Speed(mph): 120
Dimensions(in): 173 x 61.5 x 52.5
Curb Weight(lb): 3060
Fuel Economy(MPG): 19.8

XKSS.description:
Description: The 1957 Jaguar XKSS is a rare and iconic sports car with a fascinating history. Only 16 units were originally built in 19571. A factory fire destroyed nine unfinished cars, making the XKSS even rarer. In 2016, Jaguar announced a continuation series to complete the original planned production run, hand-building nine new XKSS models to the exact original specification.
Engine: Inline 6
Transmission: 4-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 5.2
Horsepower: 250
Torque(lb/ft): 260
Top Speed(mph): 149
Dimensions(in): 157.1 x 65.4 x 44.1
Curb Weight(lb): 2,030
Fuel Economy(MPG): Not Available

P1.description:

Boat Tail.description:
Description: The Rolls-Royce Boat Tail draws awesthitic from J-class yachts. It features a butterfly-style rear deck taht opens to reveal a hosting suite with a champagen refrigerator and custom made pieces. Only three have been made, and they can run owners around $28 Million.

T150 CSS.description:

Transmission: Wilson 4-speed preselector gear box

Quattro.description:

3.0 CSL.description:

Torque(lb/ft): 211
Top Speed(mph): 136.6

Curb Weight(lb): 2,403
Fuel Economy(MPG): 21.6
Description: The 1975 BMW 3.0 CSL is a legendary car, often referred to as the 'Bavarian Batmobile' due to its distinctive aerodynamic body kit. This model was a special variant of the BMW New Six Coupe, created to meet homologation requirements for the European Touring Car Championship.

328ci.description:
Engine: 3.8L inline-6
Transmission: 5-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 7.0
Horsepower: 195
Torque(lb/ft): 206
Top Speed(mph): 150
Dimensions(in): 176 x 68.5 x 55.7
Curb Weight(lb): 3,197
Fuel Economy(MPG): 19
Description: The 2000 BMW 328Ci is part of the E46 generation of the BMW 3 Series, known for its blend of performance, luxury, and style.

2002 Turbo.description:
Engine: Turbocharged 2.0L Inine-4
Transmission: 4-Speed Manual/5-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 7.0
Horsepower: 190
Torque(lb/ft): 177
Top Speed(mph):131
Dimensions(in): 166.1 x 63.8 x 55.5
Curb Weight(lb): 2,381
Fuel Economy(MPG): 21.15
Description: The 1974 BMW 2002 Turbo was the first turbocharged production car from BMW and Europe.

E30 M3.description:
Engine: Water-cooled 2.3L Inline-4
Transmission: 5-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 7
Horsepower: 192
Torque(lb/ft): 170
Top Speed(mph): 142
Dimensions(in): 171.1 x 65.9 x 53.7
Curb Weight(lb): 2,567
Fuel Economy(MPG): 24
Description: Launched in '86 the M3 features the 2.3-litre four-cylinder 'S14' engine, which shares its cast iron block with the humble M10 motor mated to a new four-valve head derived from the M5's S38 straight-six, individual throttle bodies and machined intake and exhaust ports.

Isetta 300.description:
Engine: BMW 4-Stroke
Transmission: 4-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): NA
Horsepower: 13
Torque(lb/ft): 13.6
Top Speed(mph): 53
Dimensions(in): 88.6 x 52.8 x 53
Curb Weight(lb): 778
Fuel Economy(MPG): 58
Description: The BMW Isetta 300 was a continuation of the Isetta 250, manufactured from 1957 to 1962. The updated model was due to a German government change of regulation that made producing a 250cc opposed to a 300 cc not worth it because it no longer allowed Class IV to operate anything larger than a small motorcycle. Due to a tax loophole in 1961, some Isetta's only came with three wheels.

M1.description:
Engine: 3.5L Inline-6
Transmission: 5-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 5.9
Horsepower: 277
Torque(lb/ft): 243
Top Speed(mph):
Dimensions(in): 171.7 x 71.8 x 44.9
Curb Weight(lb): 2,249
Fuel Economy(MPG): 21.9
Description: BMW intended the M1 to be the foremost expression of its automotive art. It was also intended to win races. The M1 name personifies its stature: M designates all BMW engineering projects of substance, and 1 signifies the importance in BMW engineering history.

300SL.description:
Engine:
Transmission: 3.0L Inline-6
0-60(mph): 146
Horsepower: 215
Torque(lb/ft): 228
Top Speed(mph): 163
Dimensions(in): 179 x 70.5 x 51.2
Curb Weight(lb): 2,932
Fuel Economy(MPG): 20
Description: It was the world's first four-stroke production passenger car to be equipped with output- and efficiency-enhancing direct fuel injection. Breath-taking engine output of 215 hp (158 kW) provided a top speed of 250 km/h, depending on final drive ratio. That made the 300 SL the fastest production car of its day.

540K.description:
Engine: Inline-8
Transmission: 4-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 15.5
Horsepower: 115
Torque(lb/ft): 180
Top Speed(mph): 110
Dimensions(in): 206.5 x 75 x 65
Curb Weight(lb): 6,000
Fuel Economy(MPG): 8
Description: The 1939 Mercedes-Benz 540K is a significant model in the history of Mercedes-Benz and is considered one of the most desirable cars of the Classic Era.

CLK GTR.description:
Engine: 6.9L V12
Transmission: 6-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 3.1
Horsepower: 612
Torque(lb/ft): 539
Top Speed(mph): 208
Dimensions(in): 191.1 x 76.8 x 43.3
Curb Weight(lb): 3,175
Fuel Economy(MPG): 20
Description: With its origins deeply rooted in racing history, the CLK-GTR Roadster stands as one of the most significant homologation cars ever produced. The combination of its extreme rarity, direct lineage to a championship-winning race car, and untouched condition makes it a coveted collector's item.

R107.description:
Engine: 4.5L V8
Transmission: 3-Speed Automatic
0-60(mph): 7.4
Horsepower: 204
Torque(lb/ft): 296
Top Speed(mph): 140
Dimensions(in): 172.8 x 70.5 x 51.2
Curb Weight(lb): 3,120
Fuel Economy(MPG): 18
Description: The R107 SL, a series of luxury sports cars produced by Mercedes-Benz from 1971 to 1989, experienced a notable evolution over its production span. Initially introduced as a successor to the W113 “Pagoda” SL, the R107 SL brought a modernized design and advanced features to the luxury convertible segment.

W124.description:
Engine: Inline-6
Transmission: 4-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 7.3
Horsepower: 185
Torque(lb/ft): 191
Top Speed(mph): 142
Dimensions(in): 187.2 x 68.5 x 56.3
Curb Weight(lb): 3,605
Fuel Economy(MPG): 25
Description: The W124 was considered the last true Mercedes, combining reliability with modernity, safety, and fuel efficiency. Its aerodynamics were impressive for its time, even rivaling modern cars. The W124 lineup offered a model for everyone, including sedans, wagons, and coupes, accommodating various interests and needs.

356 C.description:
Engine: 1.6L Air Cooled Flat-4
Transmission: 4-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 13.5
Horsepower: 95
Torque(lb/ft): 88
Top Speed(mph): 106.9
Dimensions(in): 158 x 65.8 x 52.4
Curb Weight(lb): 1,960
Fuel Economy(MPG): 16.7
Description: This 356 is the one that is going to attract Porsche enthusiasts and judges alike. It comes in silver metallic with red leather seats that offer a stunning color combination. Under the engine lid, the car is powered by the 1.6-liter flat 4-cylinder engine and driven by a 4-speed manual transmission.

918 Spyder.description:
Engine:4.6L V8 paired with dual electric motors
Transmission: 7-Speed Dual-Clutch Automatic
0-60(mph): 2.2
Horsepower: 887
Torque(lb/ft): 944
Top Speed(mph): 211
Dimensions(in): 182.8 nx 76.4 x 45.9
Curb Weight(lb): 3,791
Fuel Economy(MPG): 21.6
Description: On September 4, 2013, the Porsche 918 Spyder became the first street-legal vehicle with production tires to finish the 20.6 km circuit of the North Loop of the Nürburgring in less than seven minutes.

930 Turbo.description:
Engine: 3.0L Turbocharged Flat 6
Transmission: 4-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 5.5
Horsepower: 260
Torque(lb/ft): 254
Top Speed(mph): 155
Dimensions(in): 168.9 x 69.9 x 51.6
Curb Weight(lb): 2,635
Fuel Economy(MPG): 18
Description: It was the fastest production car in the world at the time of its launch and it was the flagship of the Porsche carmaker. It was hard to drive and became known as the Widowmaker, with a mystique and speed that captured a new generation of car nuts worldwide.

959.description:
Engine: Twin Turbo 2.8L Flat-6
Transmission: 6-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 4.1
Horsepower: 444
Torque(lb/ft): 369
Top Speed(mph): 195
Dimensions(in): 167.7 x 72.4 x 50.4
Curb Weight(lb): 3,197
Fuel Economy(MPG): 22
Description: In the mid-1980s, a new Porsche went on sale that looked like it had jetted in from the future – which, in many ways, it had. The twin-turbocharged 959 was considered an astonishing achievement back in 1986, regarded as the most technologically advanced road-going sportscar ever created

993.description:
Engine: 3.6L Flat-6
Transmission: 6-Speed Manual/4-Speed Tiptronic
0-60(mph): 4.7
Horsepower: 272
Torque(lb/ft): 243
Top Speed(mph): 162
Dimensions(in): 167.7 x 68.3 x 51.8
Curb Weight(lb): 3,020
Fuel Economy(MPG): 21
Description: The 993 Turbo was the first 911 Turbo with all-wheel drive, taken from the 959 flagship model. The Turbo's bodywork differs from the Carrera by widened rear wheel arches (about 6 cm), redesigned front and rear bumper moldings, and a fixed 'whale tail' rear wing housing the intercoolers.

Cayman.description:
Engine: 3.4L Flat-6
Transmission: 6-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 5.1
Horsepower: 295
Torque(lb/ft): 250.8
Top Speed(mph): 171
Dimensions(in): 170.91 x 70.91 x 51.38
Curb Weight(lb): 2,954
Fuel Economy(MPG): 22.1
Description: The 2005 Cayman was the first two-seat Porsche sports car.

GT1.description:
Engine: Twin Turbocharged 3.2L Flat-6
Transmission: 6-Speed sequential manual transmission
0-60(mph): 3.7
Horsepower: 550
Torque(lb/ft): 463
Top Speed(mph): 193
Dimensions(in): 192.5 x 78.3 x 44.9
Curb Weight(lb): 2072
Fuel Economy(MPG): 17
Description: It features the first only water-cooled mid-engine, which ensures a balanced axle-load distribution. In 1998, Porsche launches an overhauled version of the 911 GT1, featuring the first carbon fibre chassis to be used by Porsche. The vehicle shown is used by Team Zakspeed in the FIA GT World Championship in 1998.

Beetle.description:
Engine: 1.3L Flat-4
Transmission: 4-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 22
Horsepower: 50
Torque(lb/ft): 69
Top Speed(mph): 82
Dimensions(in): 160.6 x 60.6 x 59.1
Curb Weight(lb): 1,665
Fuel Economy(MPG): 20.5
Description: The 1966 Volkswagen Beetle is not just a car; it's a cultural icon that encapsulates the spirit of an era. Born in the tumultuous times of pre-war Germany and refined in the post-war period, the Beetle was the brainchild of Ferdinand Porsche, under the directive of Adolf Hitler to create a 'people's car' (Volkswagen).

CC Executive.description:
Engine: Turbocharged 2.0L Inline-4
Transmission: 7-Speed DSG
0-60(mph): 6.2
Horsepower: 220
Torque(lb/ft): 207
Top Speed(mph): 155.3
Dimensions(in): 189 x 73 x 56
Curb Weight(lb): 3,369
Fuel Economy(MPG): 25
Description: The 2014 Volkswagen CC Executive is a stylish, upscale midsize sedan with a coupe-like body. It's known for its high-quality interior, premium features, and luxury styling at a lower price than other entry-level luxury cars.

Karmann Ghia.description:
Engine: 1.3L Flat-4
Transmission: 4-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 35.5
Horsepower: 50
Torque(lb/ft): 69
Top Speed(mph): 82
Dimensions(in): 94.5 x 163 x 52.4
Curb Weight(lb): 1,765
Fuel Economy(MPG): 25
Description: The Volkswagen Karmann Ghia is a true icon of automotive design. From its origins as a stylish alternative to the Volkswagen Beetle to its status as a cult classic, the Volkswagen Karmann Ghia is a car with a rich and storied history that deserves to be celebrated.

33 Stradale.description:
Engine: 2.0L V8
Transmission: 6-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 5.9
Horsepower: 227
Torque(lb/ft): 152
Top Speed(mph): 160
Dimensions(in): 156.3 x 67.3 x 39.0
Curb Weight(lb): 1,543
Fuel Economy(MPG): 20
Description: The Alfa Romeo 33 Stradale embodies the pinnacle of 1960s race car performance, blending racing technology with road-going legality. Introduced in 1967, this car was built on an aluminum tubular chassis with a hand-crafted aluminum body, meaning a curb weight of just 1,543 pounds.

4C.description:
Engine: Turbocharged 1.7L Inline-4
Transmission: 6-Speed Dual-Clutch Automatic
0-60(mph):
Horsepower: 237
Torque(lb/ft): 258
Top Speed(mph): 160
Dimensions(in): 157 x 73.5 x 46.6
Curb Weight(lb): 2,465
Fuel Economy(MPG): 29
Description: With extensive use of aluminum, an exposed carbon-fiber monocoque structure, and a Spartan design philosophy, the 2015 4C delivers a fast, agile, unfiltered driving experience, complete with intrusive engine, and road and wind noise. Fans of seductive styling and elemental motoring will find much to enjoy here.

Spider.description:
Engine: 1.3L Inline-4
Transmission: 4-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 11.7
Horsepower: 116
Torque(lb/ft): 80.8
Top Speed(mph): 118
Dimensions(in): 152 x 62.2 x 52.6
Curb Weight(lb): 2,293
Fuel Economy(MPG): 19
Description: The 1961 Spider was a lightweight car meant for enthusiasts. Its production was continued until its termination in 1965.

308 GTB.description:
Engine: 2.9L V8
Transmission: 5-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 6.1
Horsepower: 255
Torque(lb/ft): 210
Top Speed(mph): 155
Dimensions(in): 166.5 x 67.7 x 44.1
Curb Weight(lb): 2,910
Fuel Economy(MPG): 13.1
Description: The 308 GTB made its debut at the Paris and London shows in 1975. Built to a Pininfarina design by Scaglietti, it retained the 308 GT4′s V8, albeit with dry sump lubrication. The latter made for lower engine mounting and better cooling thanks to the fact that more oil was present.

360 Modena.description:
Engine: 3.6L V8
Transmission: 6-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 3.7
Horsepower: 400
Torque(lb/ft): 285
Top Speed(mph): 183
Dimensions(in): 176.3 x 75.7 x 48.6
Curb Weight(lb): 2,601
Fuel Economy(MPG): 13
Description: The Modena is named after the birthplace of Enzo Ferarri in Modena, Italy.

Enzo.description:
Engine: 6.0L V12
Transmission: 6-Speed Maumatic
0-60(mph): 3.3
Horsepower: 660
Torque(lb/ft): 485
Top Speed(mph): 218
Dimensions(in): 185.1 x 80.1 x 45.2
Curb Weight(lb): 3,230
Fuel Economy(MPG): 14.9
Description: It might be hard to believe, but the Enzo was introduced over two decades ago. While the F40 and F50 were produced to honor anniversaries, the Enzo was introduced to celebrate the success of Ferrari's Formula 1 team. It is fitting that the car designed to honor Enzo Ferrari's passion is named after him.

F40.description:
Engine: Twin Turbocharged 2.9L V8
Transmission: 5-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 3.8
Horsepower: 471
Torque(lb/ft): 426
Top Speed(mph): 201
Dimensions(in): 171.5 x 77.6 x 46.3
Curb Weight(lb): 2,765
Fuel Economy(MPG): 19
Description: As the successor to the 288 GTO (also engineered by Materazzi), it was designed to celebrate Ferrari's 40th anniversary and was the last Ferrari automobile personally approved by Enzo Ferrari. At the time it was Ferrari's fastest, most powerful, and most expensive car for sale.

F50.description:
Engine: 4.7L V12
Transmission: 6-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 3.8
Horsepower: 512
Torque(lb/ft): 347
Top Speed(mph): 202
Dimensions(in): 176.4 x 78.2 x 44.1
Curb Weight(lb): 3,080
Fuel Economy(MPG): 8
Description: The F50s design draws heavily from Ferrari's formula team. It also marked the 50th year of Ferrari's operations

GTO.description:
Engine: 3.0L V12
Transmission: 5-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 6.1
Horsepower: 300
Torque(lb/ft): 217
Top Speed(mph): 174
Dimensions(in): 170.3 x 63 x 47.6
Curb Weight(lb): 1,940
Fuel Economy(MPG): 12
Description: The 250 GTO was the ultimate expression of the Ferrari 250 GT car. It was equally at home on the road or track – perhaps the last dual purpose road/race car produced – and has achieved legendary status amongst aficionados of the marque.

La Ferarri.description:
Engine: 6.3L V12 paired with a 150hp electric motor
Transmission: 7-Speed Automatic
0-60(mph): 2.4
Horsepower: 950
Torque(lb/ft): 516
Top Speed(mph): 220
Dimensions(in): 185.1 x 78.4 x 43.9
Curb Weight(lb): 3,009
Fuel Economy(MPG): 16.7
Description: The LaFerrari delivered many firsts for a Ferrari road cars but perhaps the most notable are its debuting of the HY-KERS hybrid technology, which both maximises performance and reduces fuel consumption. It also came with active aerodynamics

Testarossa.description:
Engine: 4.9L Flat-12
Transmission: 5-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 5.2
Horsepower: 380
Torque(lb/ft): 354
Top Speed(mph): 180
Dimensions(in): 176.6 x 77.8 x 44.5
Curb Weight(lb): 3,020
Fuel Economy(MPG): 18
Description: While it was more civilized and refined than the 512 BB, the wild looks and performance made the Testarossa a proper supercar. Testarossa sales success for Ferrari and a pop-culture icon that inspired countless copycats throughout the 80s and 90s.

Countach.description:
Engine: 5.2L V12
Transmission: 5-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 4.8
Horsepower: 450
Torque(lb/ft): 369
Top Speed(mph): 185
Dimensions(in): 163 x 78.7 x 42.1
Curb Weight(lb): 3,280
Fuel Economy(MPG): 17.4
Description: The Coutach had an increase in power compared to previous Lamborghinis. It quickly became a culutural icon and continues to be one today.

Gallardo.description:
Engine: 5.0L V10
Transmission: 6-Speed Manual
0-60(mph): 4.2
Horsepower: 494
Torque(lb/ft): 376
Top Speed(mph): 192
Dimensions(in): 169 x 75 x 46
Curb Weight(lb): 3,153
Fuel Economy(MPG): 10
Description: The Gallardo was the best selling model during its production run with over 14,000 units being sold. This gave the company financial stability and allowed Lamborghini to continue producing cars at a more comfortable rate.
